reviewText: I really like the concept of this film but had concerns about ethics, the brevity and superficialities of some activities at camp, and clinical prudence that I witnessed. I did appreciate the children's honesty. That was the best part of the film.

This documentary was very good and I had tears in my eyes multiple times, however, I think bringing in older survivors who experienced this type of grief would have helped.  I say that because I lost my Father when he was 48 and my only Brother when he was 30.  I was 28 years old at the time and the pain was enormous.  I worked through that pain and I came out the other side,.
Very touching. Gives an insight to how children process grief.

A poignant look into the possibility of transforming a child's grief after the loss of a loved one in a very special space called Camp Erin. A tribute to the human spirit, both of the adults who hold open the space of healing for small broken hearts and the children who become able & move to feel their losses and move on in life. A beautify experience to witness and a testament to the power of love.
Incredible story of children trying to deal with a great loss, compassion, caring and kindness shines through.
